item.title: How to Book Kimpton Hotels Free with Points
item.description:
If you’ve traveled with a large dog, you know the drill: call ahead, confirm the weight limit, hope they don’t give you a hard time at check-in. It gets old.

Kimpton doesn’t play that game. Their policy is simple: if your pet fits through the door, they’re welcome. No weight limit. No breed restrictions. No pet fee. Ever.

It’s the most genuinely pet-friendly hotel chain I’ve found â€” and you can book stays completely free using credit card points.

Jump to:

  • Why Kimpton for Pet Travelers
  • How to Earn IHG Points
  • IHG Credit Cards
  • Chase Transfer Partners
  • How Many Points You’ll Need
  • Best Kimptons for Dogs
  • Which Card Should You Get?

Why Kimpton for Pet Travelers

Kimpton became the first major hotel chain to go pet-friendly back in 1992. They weren’t just tolerating pets â€” they built it into the brand. Here’s what you actually get:

  • No pet fee â€” not even for extended stays
  • No weight or breed restrictions â€” Great Danes, pit bulls, whatever
  • Pet amenities included â€” loaner beds, bowls, treats at check-in
  • Pet-friendly wine hour â€” the nightly hosted reception welcomes dogs
  • Director of Pet Relations at some properties â€” yes, it’s a dog

With 77+ locations in the US and a few international properties, you’ve got solid coverage in most major cities.

The catch? Kimpton is a boutique brand, so rates tend to run higher than your typical Hilton or Marriott. That’s where points come in.

How to Earn IHG Points for Kimpton

Kimpton is part of IHG (InterContinental Hotels Group), so you book using IHG One Rewards points. There are two main ways to stack up enough points for free stays:

  1. IHG credit cards (direct earning)
  2. Chase Ultimate Rewards (transfer partner)

Option 1: IHG Credit Cards

If you stay at IHG properties regularly, their co-branded Chase cards make sense.

ğŸ’ IHG One Rewards Premier Credit Card

The card for frequent IHG travelers.
Annual Fee $99
Sign-Up Bonus 140,000 points after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Free Night 1/year at properties up to 40,000 points
Status Platinum Elite

That 140,000-point bonus is enough for 2-4 free nights at most Kimptons, depending on the property and dates.

Key perks:

  • ğŸ’³ 26x points at IHG properties
  • âœˆï¸ 5x on travel, gas, and restaurants
  • ğŸŒ™ 4th night free on award stays (book 4, pay for 3)
  • ğŸ Annual free night certificate

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: The 4th night free benefit is huge. If you’re booking a 4-night Kimpton stay with points, you’re effectively getting 25% off. A 200,000-point redemption becomes 150,000.

How the $99 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $200+
4th night free on award stays Varies
Total $200+

ğŸ†“ IHG One Rewards Traveler Credit Card

The no-risk starting point.

Sign-Up Bonus 80,000 points after $2,000 spend in 3 months
Free Night None
Status None

If you’re not sure how often you’ll stay at IHG properties, this is a safe way to start earning points. 80,000 points for $2,000 in spending with no annual fee is solid.

Key perks:

  • ğŸ’³ 17x points at IHG properties
  • ğŸ½ï¸ 3x on dining, gas, and groceries
  • ğŸŒ™ 4th night free on award stays (yes, even with the no-fee card)

Option 2: Chase Ultimate Rewards Transfer

If you want more flexibility, Chase Ultimate Rewards points transfer 1:1 to IHG. This is my preferred approach because I can use the same points for flights, other hotels, or cash back if I need to.

Cards that earn transferable Ultimate Rewards:

Chase Sapphire Preferred

Annual Fee $95
Sign-Up Bonus 60,000 points after $4,000 spend in 3 months
  • 3x on dining, select streaming, and online groceries
  • 2x on travel
  • Points transfer to 14+ airline and hotel partners including IHG

Annual Fee $550
Sign-Up Bonus 60,000 points after $4,000 spend in 3 months
  • 3x on dining and travel
  • $300 annual travel credit (effectively reduces fee to $250)
  • Priority Pass lounge access
  • Points worth 1.5x when booked through Chase Travel

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: If you already have a Sapphire card for travel, you don’t need an IHG card. Just transfer points when you find a Kimpton you want to book. Transfers are instant.

How Many Points Do Kimpton Stays Cost?

IHG uses dynamic pricing, so point costs vary by property, date, and demand. Here’s what I’ve seen:

Demand Points/Night Example
Off-peak 20,000â€“35,000 Midweek in shoulder season
Standard 40,000â€“60,000 Most weekends
Peak 70,000â€“100,000+ Holidays, special events

For reference, I searched Kimpton Hotel Monaco Denver for a random February weekend and found award nights around 45,000 points. Paid rates were $280/night, so that’s solid value.

Remember: If you have the IHG Premier card, book 4 nights and the 4th is free. That 180,000-point booking becomes 135,000.

Best Kimpton Properties for Dog Travelers

Not every Kimpton is equal when it comes to dog-friendliness (location matters). Here are some I’ve researched or have on my list:

ğŸ”ï¸ Kimpton Hotel Monaco Denver

Downtown location with easy access to trails. The wine hour is popular, and staff are known for going above and beyond for pets. Close to Cherry Creek Dog Park.

ğŸŒ³ Kimpton Brice Hotel (Savannah)

Enclosed courtyard that’s perfect for the evening wine reception with your pup. Walking distance to Forsyth Park â€” one of the most dog-friendly parks in the South.

ğŸŒ´ Kimpton Rowan Palm Springs

Near several dog parks and surrounded by pet-friendly restaurant patios. Great for a desert getaway when it’s not 115Â°F.

ğŸ”ï¸ Kimpton Arras (Asheville)

Gateway to Blue Ridge Mountains hiking. Asheville is extremely dog-friendly, with tons of outdoor dining and brewery patios that welcome dogs.

ğŸº Kimpton Journeyman (Milwaukee)

Dedicated pet-friendly floors. Good urban location for exploring with your dog.

Which Card Should You Get?

You… Get This Why
ğŸ†• New to points IHG Traveler 80k bonus, no fee, no risk
ğŸ¨ Stay at IHG often IHG Premier 140k bonus, free night, 4th night free
âœˆï¸ Want flexibility Chase Sapphire Preferred Transfer to IHG + 13 other partners
ğŸ’ Already have Hilton cards Chase Sapphire Preferred Add IHG as a transfer option

If you’re already in the Hilton ecosystem (like me), the Sapphire Preferred is a good complement. You keep your Hilton setup for most trips and transfer Chase points to IHG when you want to book a Kimpton.

The Bottom Line

Kimpton is the best hotel chain for pet travelers, full stop. No other major brand matches their policy â€” no fees, no weight limits, no breed restrictions, and actual pet amenities beyond a sad bowl at the front desk.

The only downside is price. Kimpton properties aren’t cheap. But that’s exactly why points matter here. A $300/night boutique hotel stay feels very different when it costs you 45,000 points you earned from everyday spending.

If you’re traveling with a large dog and want a stress-free check-in experience, Kimpton should be on your radar. And now you know how to book it free.

Have you stayed at a Kimpton with your dog? I’d love to hear which property â€” reach out and let me know.

item.title: Hilton Diamond Status: How to Get It and Why It's Worth It
item.description:
Hilton Diamond is the top tier of Hilton Honors (until Diamond Reserve launches in 2026), and it comes with perks that make traveling with a dog way easier â€” room upgrades, late checkout, free breakfast, and more.

Here’s how I got it and why it’s worth pursuing.

ğŸ’ How I Got Diamond Status

I earned Diamond status two ways:

First time: I hit the $40,000 spending threshold on my Hilton Surpass card through everyday spending â€” groceries, gas, dining, bills. Once you hit that number, Diamond status kicks in within a few weeks.

Now: I carry the Hilton Aspire card, which gives you automatic Diamond status just for having the card. No spending threshold, no stays required â€” you’re Diamond from day one.

If you’re serious about hotel travel, the Aspire is the easier path. If you’re already putting significant spend on a Surpass card, you might hit Diamond that way first.

â­ Diamond Status Benefits

Benefit What It Means

ğŸ³ Daily food & beverage credit At U.S. properties (or free breakfast internationally)

ğŸ’¯ 100% bonus points Double the base points on every stay

ğŸ“¶ Premium WiFi Fastest speeds in the hotel
âœ… 48-hour room guarantee Guaranteed room if booked 48+ hours ahead
ğŸ Welcome amenities Snacks, water bottles, treats at check-in (varies by property)

ğŸ¨ The Perks I Actually Use

Room Upgrades

This is the big one. As a Diamond member, I’ve been upgraded to suites multiple times â€” including an ocean-view suite at the Embassy Suites in Panama City Beach. More space means more room for the dog to spread out, and a balcony is a game-changer for morning coffee while Ansel watches the beach.

Pro tip: When you book, add a note requesting an upgrade. It doesn’t guarantee anything, but it puts you on their radar.

Daily Food & Beverage Credit

At most U.S. Hilton properties, Diamond members get a daily F&B credit instead of free breakfast. The amount varies by brand (usually $15â€“$25 per person), and it applies to you plus one guest.

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: These credits stack. Staying 3 nights? That’s 3 days of credits you can use whenever â€” save them up and have a nice dinner on your last night, or use them at the bar.

Late Checkout

When you’re traveling with a dog, late checkout is clutch. No rushing to pack up and get the dog out by 11am. I’ve gotten 2pm checkout at most properties just by asking at the front desk.

Executive Lounge Access

Where available, Diamond members can access the executive lounge for free breakfast, evening appetizers, and drinks. These are more common at international properties â€” in the U.S., they’re hit or miss. But when you find one, it’s a nice quiet spot to grab coffee or a snack.

Welcome Amenities

This varies by property, but I’ve received complimentary water bottles, snacks, and even treats for Ansel at check-in. Small touches that make you feel recognized.

ğŸ¯ Ways to Earn Diamond Status

Method Requirement
ğŸ’³ Hilton Aspire card Automatic â€” just have the card
ğŸ’³ Hilton Surpass card Spend $40,000 in a calendar year
ğŸ›ï¸ Stays 30 stays in a calendar year
ğŸŒ™ Nights 60 nights in a calendar year
â­ Base points Earn 120,000 base points in a calendar year

For most people, the credit card path is the easiest. Unless you’re traveling for work constantly, hitting 60 nights is tough. But everyday spending on a Surpass or Aspire card? That adds up fast.

ğŸ’³ The Credit Card Shortcut

Hilton Aspire ($550/year)

  • Automatic Diamond status â€” no spend required
  • Annual free night certificate
  • $400/year in Hilton resort credits
  • $200/year in flight credits (buy airline gift cards â€” they count!)
  • 175,000 point sign-up bonus

Hilton Surpass ($150/year)

  • Gold status automatic, Diamond at $40k spend
  • $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter â€” use at any Hilton property, even just for dinner)
  • Free night after $15k spend
  • 155,000 point sign-up bonus

If you want Diamond without the $550 Aspire fee, the Surpass path works â€” it just takes more spending. I did it for a couple years before upgrading to the Aspire.

For the full breakdown, check out my Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers guide.

ğŸŒ™ Free Night Certificates: The Secret Weapon

One of my favorite Diamond perks isn’t technically a Diamond perk â€” it’s the free night certificates from the Aspire card. But here’s what most people don’t realize:

These certificates work at almost any Hilton property.

I’ve used mine at resorts where rooms go for $400â€“$500/night. Some people have used them at properties charging $1,000+ per night. The certificate covers one standard night, regardless of the cash price.

So while you’re earning Diamond status and racking up points, those free night certificates are quietly saving you hundreds of dollars per year.

ğŸ• Why Diamond Matters for Pet Travelers

Here’s why I think Diamond status is especially valuable when you’re traveling with a dog:

  1. Suite upgrades = more space. A regular hotel room with a 70-pound dog feels cramped. A suite with a separate living area? Much better.

  2. Late checkout = less stress. Morning potty breaks, packing up dog gear, loading the car â€” it all takes longer with a pet. Late checkout gives you breathing room.

  3. F&B credits = save money. Pet fees add up. Having your meals partially covered helps offset those costs.

  4. Welcome amenities. Some properties include dog treats or pet welcome packages for Diamond members. It’s not guaranteed, but it happens.

ğŸ“… What’s Coming: Diamond Reserve (2026)

Hilton is adding a new tier above Diamond starting January 2026 â€” Diamond Reserve. It requires 80 nights or 40 stays PLUS $18,000 in eligible spend.

The perks include confirmable suite upgrades at booking, guaranteed 4pm late checkout, and 120% bonus points. For most travelers, regular Diamond will still be the goal â€” but it’s good to know what’s coming.

The good news: nothing changes for current Diamond members. All the existing benefits stay the same.

âœ… The Bottom Line

Diamond status makes hotel travel more comfortable â€” especially with a dog. The upgrades, late checkout, and F&B credits add real value, and the credit card path makes it accessible even if you’re not a road warrior.

If you’re already staying at Hilton properties and putting spend on a Hilton card, Diamond is within reach. And once you have it, you’ll wonder how you traveled without it.
